content.text:
# Your Job

Scan https://github.com/zeroclaw-labs/zeroclaw, https://github.com/openclaw/openclaw, and https://github.com/stephengpope/thepopebot for new tools, skills, and architectures. Pick the best new idea and actually WRITE the code to implement it as a new PopeBot skill in your sandbox (.pi/skills/). Write and execute a test to prove it works. Use the send_email tool to email winsorllc@yahoo.com a progress report detailing what you built, how you implemented it, your test results, and code samples so the user can review it at 8 AM.

content.thinking:
The user wants me to:
1. Scan three GitHub repositories for new tools, skills, and architectures
2. Pick the best new idea
3. Implement it as a new PopeBot skill in the sandbox (.pi/skills/)
4. Write and execute a test to prove it works
5. Use the send_email tool to email a progress report to winsorllc@yahoo.com

Let me start by exploring these repositories. I'll need to clone or fetch information from them. Since I have the browser-tools skill available, I could use that, but for GitHub repos, it's more efficient to use git clone or the GitHub API.

Let me first check what's already in my environment and then clone these repos to explore them.

Actually, I should use the skill-discovery skill which is designed for "Automatically discover, evaluate, and generate manifests for new PopeBot skills from GitHub." Let me read that skill first to understand how to use it.

But first, let me check the current state of my .pi/skills/ directory and understand the structure better.

content.text: I'll systematically scan those repositories, find the best new idea, implement it as a skill, and email you a progress report. Let me start by exploring the repositories and understanding the current skill architecture.

content.text:
---
name: nano-pdf
description: Edit PDFs with natural-language instructions using the nano-pdf CLI.
homepage: https://pypi.org/project/nano-pdf/
metadata:
  {
    "openclaw":
      {
        "emoji": "üìÑ",
        "requires": { "bins": ["nano-pdf"] },
        "install":
          [
            {
              "id": "uv",
              "kind": "uv",
              "package": "nano-pdf",
              "bins": ["nano-pdf"],
              "label": "Install nano-pdf (uv)",
            },
          ],
      },
  }
---

# nano-pdf

Use `nano-pdf` to apply edits to a specific page in a PDF using a natural-language instruction.

## Quick start

```bash
nano-pdf edit deck.pdf 1 "Change the title to 'Q3 Results' and fix the typo in the subtitle"
```

Notes:

- Page numbers are 0-based or 1-based depending on the tool‚Äôs version/config; if the result looks off by one, retry with the other.
- Always sanity-check the output PDF before sending it out.

# Video Frames (ffmpeg)

Extract a single frame from a video, or create quick thumbnails for inspection.

## Quick start

First frame:

```bash
{baseDir}/scripts/frame.sh /path/to/video.mp4 --out /tmp/frame.jpg
```

At a timestamp:

```bash
{baseDir}/scripts/frame.sh /path/to/video.mp4 --time 00:00:10 --out /tmp/frame-10s.jpg
```

## Notes

- Prefer `--time` for ‚Äúwhat is happening around here?‚Äù.
- Use a `.jpg` for quick share; use `.png` for crisp UI frames.

---

# oracle ‚Äî best use

Oracle bundles your prompt + selected files into one ‚Äúone-shot‚Äù request so another model can answer with real repo context (API or browser automation). Treat output as advisory: verify against code + tests.

## Main use case (browser, GPT‚Äë5.2 Pro)

Default workflow here: `--engine browser` with GPT‚Äë5.2 Pro in ChatGPT. This is the common ‚Äúlong think‚Äù path: ~10 minutes to ~1 hour is normal; expect a stored session you can reattach to.

Recommended defaults:

- Engine: browser (`--engine browser`)
- Model: GPT‚Äë5.2 Pro (`--model gpt-5.2-pro` or `--model "5.2 Pro"`)

## Golden path

1. Pick a tight file set (fewest files that still contain the truth).
2. Preview payload + token spend (`--dry-run` + `--files-report`).
3. Use browser mode for the usual GPT‚Äë5.2 Pro workflow; use API only when you explicitly want it.
4. If the run detaches/timeouts: reattach to the stored session (don‚Äôt re-run).

## Commands (preferred)

- Help:
  - `oracle --help`
  - If the binary isn‚Äôt installed: `npx -y @steipete/oracle --help` (avoid `pnpx` here; sqlite bindings).

- Preview (no tokens):
  - `oracle --dry-run summary -p "<task>" --file "src/**" --file "!**/*.test.*"`
  - `oracle --dry-run full -p "<task>" --file "src/**"`

- Token sanity:
  - `oracle --dry-run summary --files-report -p "<task>" --file "src/**"`

- Browser run (main path; long-running is normal):
  - `oracle --engine browser --model gpt-5.2-pro -p "<task>" --file "src/**"`

- Manual paste fallback:
  - `oracle --render --copy -p "<task>" --file "src/**"`
  - Note: `--copy` is a hidden alias for `--copy-markdown`.

## Attaching files (`--file`)

`--file` accepts files, directories, and globs. You can pass it multiple times; entries can be comma-separated.

- Include:
  - `--file "src/**"`
  - `--file src/index.ts`
  - `--file docs --file README.md`

- Exclude:
  - `--file "src/**" --file "!src/**/*.test.ts" --file "!**/*.snap"`

- Defaults (implementation behavior):
  - Default-ignored dirs: `node_modules`, `dist`, `coverage`, `.git`, `.turbo`, `.next`, `build`, `tmp` (skipped unless explicitly passed as literal dirs/files).
  - Honors `.gitignore` when expanding globs.
  - Does not follow symlinks.
  - Dotfiles filtered unless opted in via pattern (e.g. `--file ".github/**"`).
  - Files > 1 MB rejected.

## Engines (API vs browser)

- Auto-pick: `api` when `OPENAI_API_KEY` is set; otherwise `browser`.
- Browser supports GPT + Gemini only; use `--engine api` for Claude/Grok/Codex or multi-model runs.
- Browser attachments:
  - `--browser-attachments auto|never|always` (auto pastes inline up to ~60k chars then uploads).
- Remote browser host:
  - Host: `oracle serve --host 0.0.0.0 --port 9473 --token <secret>`
  - Client: `oracle --engine browser --remote-host <host:port> --remote-token <secret> -p "<task>" --file "src/**"`

## Sessions + slugs

- Stored under `~/.oracle/sessions` (override with `ORACLE_HOME_DIR`).
- Runs may detach or take a long time (browser + GPT‚Äë5.2 Pro often does). If the CLI times out: don‚Äôt re-run; reattach.
  - List: `oracle status --hours 72`
  - Attach: `oracle session <id> --render`
- Use `--slug "<3-5 words>"` to keep session IDs readable.
- Duplicate prompt guard exists; use `--force` only when you truly want a fresh run.

## Prompt template (high signal)

Oracle starts with **zero** project knowledge. Assume the model cannot infer your stack, build tooling, conventions, or ‚Äúobvious‚Äù paths. Include:

- Project briefing (stack + build/test commands + platform constraints).
- ‚ÄúWhere things live‚Äù (key directories, entrypoints, config files, boundaries).
- Exact question + what you tried + the error text (verbatim).
- Constraints (‚Äúdon‚Äôt change X‚Äù, ‚Äúmust keep public API‚Äù, etc).
- Desired output (‚Äúreturn patch plan + tests‚Äù, ‚Äúgive 3 options with tradeoffs‚Äù).

## Safety

- Don‚Äôt attach secrets by default (`.env`, key files, auth tokens). Redact aggressively; share only what‚Äôs required.

## ‚ÄúExhaustive prompt‚Äù restoration pattern

For long investigations, write a standalone prompt + file set so you can rerun days later:

- 6‚Äì30 sentence project briefing + the goal.
- Repro steps + exact errors + what you tried.
- Attach all context files needed (entrypoints, configs, key modules, docs).

Oracle runs are one-shot; the model doesn‚Äôt remember prior runs. ‚ÄúRestoring context‚Äù means re-running with the same prompt + `--file ‚Ä¶` set (or reattaching a still-running stored session).

# OpenHue CLI

Use `openhue` to control Philips Hue lights and scenes via a Hue Bridge.

## When to Use

‚úÖ **USE this skill when:**

- "Turn on/off the lights"
- "Dim the living room lights"
- "Set a scene" or "movie mode"
- Controlling specific Hue rooms or zones
- Adjusting brightness, color, or color temperature

## When NOT to Use

‚ùå **DON'T use this skill when:**

- Non-Hue smart devices (other brands) ‚Üí not supported
- HomeKit scenes or Shortcuts ‚Üí use Apple's ecosystem
- TV or entertainment system control
- Thermostat or HVAC
- Smart plugs (unless Hue smart plugs)

## Common Commands

### List Resources

```bash
openhue get light       # List all lights
openhue get room        # List all rooms
openhue get scene       # List all scenes
```

### Control Lights

```bash
# Turn on/off
openhue set light "Bedroom Lamp" --on
openhue set light "Bedroom Lamp" --off

# Brightness (0-100)
openhue set light "Bedroom Lamp" --on --brightness 50

# Color temperature (warm to cool: 153-500 mirek)
openhue set light "Bedroom Lamp" --on --temperature 300

# Color (by name or hex)
openhue set light "Bedroom Lamp" --on --color red
openhue set light "Bedroom Lamp" --on --rgb "#FF5500"
```

### Control Rooms

```bash
# Turn off entire room
openhue set room "Bedroom" --off

# Set room brightness
openhue set room "Bedroom" --on --brightness 30
```

### Scenes

```bash
# Activate scene
openhue set scene "Relax" --room "Bedroom"
openhue set scene "Concentrate" --room "Office"
```

## Quick Presets

```bash
# Bedtime (dim warm)
openhue set room "Bedroom" --on --brightness 20 --temperature 450

# Work mode (bright cool)
openhue set room "Office" --on --brightness 100 --temperature 250

# Movie mode (dim)
openhue set room "Living Room" --on --brightness 10
```

## Notes

- Bridge must be on local network
- First run requires button press on Hue bridge to pair
- Colors only work on color-capable bulbs (not white-only)
